text: Green tea (GT) alters the disposition of a number of drugs, such as nadolol and lisinopril.
label: Herb name
Drug
Drug

text: However, it is unknown whether GT affects disposition of hydrophilic anti‐allergic drugs.
label: Herb name
Drug

text: The purpose of this study was to investigate whether pharmacokinetics of fexofenadine and pseudoephedrine are affected by catechins, major GT components.
label: Drug
Drug
Herb name
Herb name

text: A randomized, open, 2‐phase crossover study was conducted in 10 healthy Japanese volunteers.
label: Study
Cohort
Pathology
Ethnic group

text: After overnight fasting, subjects were simultaneously administered fexofenadine (60 mg) and pseudoephedrine (120 mg) with an aqueous solution of green tea extract (GTE) containing (−)‐epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG) of ~ 300 mg or water (control).
label: Drug
Amount
Drug
Amount
Extraction process
Herb name
Herb name
Amount

text: In vitro transport assays were performed using HEK293 cells stably expressing organic anion transporting polypeptide (OATP)1A2 to evaluate the inhibitory effect of EGCG on OATP1A2‐mediated fexofenadine transport.
label: Herb name
Target
Parameter
Drug

text: In the GTE phase, the area under the plasma concentration‐time curve and the amount excreted unchanged into urine for 24 hours of fexofenadine were significantly decreased by 70% (P < 0.001) and 67% (P < 0.001), respectively, compared with control.
label: Herb name
Parameter
Parameter
Duration
Drug
Amount
Amount

text: There were no differences in time to maximum plasma concentration and the elimination half‐life of fexofenadine between phases.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Drug

text: Fexofenadine was confirmed to be a substrate of OATP1A2, and EGCG (100 and 1,000 μM) and GTE (0.1 and 1 mg/mL) inhibited OATP1A2‐mediated uptake of fexofenadine.
label: Drug
Target
Herb name
Amount
Amount
Herb name
Amount
Amount
Target
Parameter
Drug

text: On the contrary, the concomitant administration of GTE did not influence the pharmacokinetics of pseudoephedrine.
label: Herb name
Drug

text: These results suggest that intake of GT may result in a markedly reduced exposure of fexofenadine, but not of pseudoephedrine, putatively by inhibiting OATP1A2‐mediated intestinal absorption.
label: Herb name

text: WHAT IS THE CURRENT KNOWLEDGE ON THE TOPIC?
☑ Green tea (GT) and its catechin components interact with hydrophilic drugs, such as nadolol and lisinopril.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Drug
Drug

text: A combination of fexofenadine and pseudoephedrine is clinically available for treatment of allergic rhinitis.
label: Drug
Drug
Pathology

text: WHAT QUESTION DID THIS STUDY ADDRESS?
☑ This study evaluated whether pharmacokinetics of fexofenadine and pseudoephedrine are affected when orally administered with an aqueous solution of green tea extract (GTE) in healthy volunteers.
label: Drug
Drug
Extraction process
Herb name
Pathology

text: WHAT DOES THIS STUDY ADD TO OUR KNOWLEDGE?
☑ Plasma concentrations and urinary excretions of fexofenadine were markedly decreased when coadministered with GTE, containing ~ 300 mg of (−)‐epigallocatechin gallate.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Drug
Herb name
Amount
Herb name

text: GTE and (−)‐epigallocatechin gallate significantly inhibited OATP1A2‐mediated fexofenadine uptake.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Target
Parameter
Drug

text: No differences were observed in the pharmacokinetics of pseudoephedrine between water and GTE.
label: Drug
Herb name

text: HOW MIGHT THIS CHANGE CLINICAL PHARMACOLOGY OR TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCE?
☑ GT and its catechin supplement reduce oral bioavailability of fexofenadine, but not of pseudoephedrine.
label: Herb name
Herb name

Drug

text: The inhibition of intestinal OATP1A2 by (−)‐epigallocatechin gallate is a likely mechanism underlying this interaction.
label: Target
Herb name

text: Green tea (GT; Camellia sinensis) and its main components, catechins, are perpetrators of clinically relevant food‐drug interactions with hydrophilic and nonmetabolized drugs, such as nadolol and lisinopril.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Drug
Drug

text: The H At present, a combined tablet of fexofenadine and pseudoephedrine, a nasal decongestant, is available for the treatment of allergic rhinitis in several countries, such as the United States (Allegra‐D) and Japan (Dellegra).
label: Drug
Drug
Pathology
Drug
Drug

text: Taking into account the anti‐allergic potential of GT and catechins,  Ten healthy nonsmoking Japanese volunteers (8 men and 2 women) participated in this study with an age range of 21–45 years and body mass index of 18.4–26.0 kg/m The study protocol was approved by the ethics committee of the Fukushima Medical University (approval number: RK29037) and was registered at the UMIN Clinical Trials Registry (UMIN000032828).
label: Herb name
Herb name
Cohort
Pathology
Ethnic group

Sex
Age
Parameter

Study

text: The study was conducted in compliance with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki.

In a single‐center, open‐label, randomized 2‐way crossover study with a washout period of 2 weeks, the participants ingested a single oral dose of 2 tablets of fexofenadine (30 mg × 2) and (+)‐pseudoephedrine (sustained‐release formulation, 60 mg × 2; Dellegra; LTL Pharma, Tokyo, Japan) simultaneously with 150 mL of an aqueous solution of a commercial GTE (Sunphenon‐EGCG, Taiyo Kagaku, Yokkaichi, Japan) or with 150 mL of water after overnight fasting.
label: Study

Herb name
Herb name
Amount

text: The GTE contained 92.5% (w/w) of EGCG, and 325 mg of which was dissolved in water with stirring.
label: Herb name
Amount
Herb name
Amount

text: Subjects had a snack at 1 hour and a standardized meal at 4 hours after administration.
label: Duration
Duration

text: In each study period, 5 mL venous blood samples were collected from an indwelling catheter placed in an antecubital vein or by direct venipuncture into EDTA‐treated tubes at 0, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, and 24 hours after administration.
label: Amount
Duration

text: Blood samples were immediately centrifuged at 2,000 g for 10 minutes at 4°C.
label: Amount
Duration
Parameter

text: Urine was collected during periods of 0–4, 4–8, and 8–24 hours after administration.
label: Duration
Duration
Duration

text: Plasma and urine samples were stored at −80°C until analysis.
label: Parameter

text: The concentrations of fexofenadine and pseudoephedrine in plasma and urine were determined using ultra‐performance liquid chromatography (UPLC) with fluorescence detection (UPLC, Waters, Milford, MA), as summarized in  Methods S1 .
label: Drug
Drug

text: Diphenhydramine and phenylephrine were used as internal standards for fexofenadine and pseudoephedrine, respectively.
label: Drug
Drug
Drug
Drug

text: The limit of quantification for fexofenadine and pseudoephedrine was both 10 ng/mL.
label: Drug
Drug
Amount

text: The inter‐day coefficients of variation of fexofenadine and pseudoephedrine were 9.9% and 7.3%, respectively.
label: Drug
Drug
Amount
Amount

text: To test whether GTE and EGCG affect OATP1A2‐ and OATP2B1‐mediated uptake of fexofenadine, we performed in vitro transport assays using OATP1A2‐ and OATP2B1‐stably expressing HEK cells and the respective HEK‐VC vector control cells.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Target
Target
Parameter
Drug

text: Sulfobromophthalein (BSP) was used as a typical substrate for OATP2B1.
label: Drug
Target

text: The transporter‐expressing cells and the respective vector control cells were cultured according to previous studies.

To examine the possibility of direct chemical binding between fexofenadine and EGCG in the gastrointestinal tract, fexofenadine (400 μg/mL, based on the maximum concentration when a 60‐mg dose was dissolved in 150 mL) was incubated in the presence or absence of EGCG (1 mg/mL) in saline at 37°C for 1, 2, and 24 hours.

**P < 0.01, vs. uptake into HEK293 control cells (PQX or VC);  It has been reported that GT catechins chemically interacted with various kinds of drugs including bortezomib, a proteasome inhibitor (Figure  S4  a).
label: Herb name
Drug

text: In this study, we report that a single concomitant ingestion of an aqueous solution (150 mL) of GTE containing about 300 mg of EGCG (~ 4.4 mM), significantly decreases plasma concentrations and urinary excretion of fexofenadine when compared with water (control) in healthy volunteers (Figures 1, 2).
label: Extraction process
Amount
Herb name
Amount
Herb name
Amount
Parameter
Parameter
Drug
Pathology

text: In contrast, no substantial differences were observed in the pharmacokinetics of pseudoephedrine between GTE and control phases (Figures 3, 4).
label: Drug
Herb name

text: Fexofenadine and pseudoephedrine have common properties in terms of high hydrophilicity and negligible oxidative metabolism in the body, whereas the oral bioavailability of fexofenadine (35%) is considerably lower than that of pseudoephedrine (≈100%).
label: Drug
Drug
Parameter
Drug
Amount
Parameter
Drug
Amount

text: Regarding the molecular mechanisms for reduced exposure of fexofenadine after oral administration, it is well known that the intestinal absorption of fexofenadine is highly dependent on transporter‐mediated uptake and/or efflux, and that inhibition of the relevant transporters by co‐administered drugs or food could result in a significant impact on its pharmacokinetics.
label: Drug
Parameter
Drug

text: A second possible mechanism is a direct chemical interaction between fexofenadine and EGCG.
label: Drug
Herb name

text: Indeed, various drugs, including aripiprazole, bortezomib, cetirizine, and sunitinib, has been reported to interact with EGCG.
label: Drug
Drug
Drug
Drug
Herb name

text: In contrast to fexofenadine, the plasma concentration‐time profile and cumulative urinary excretions of pseudoephedrine were similar in both phases, suggesting that EGCG had no impact on pseudoephedrine pharmacokinetics (Figures 3, 4).
label: Drug
Parameter
Parameter
Drug
Herb name
Drug

text: Due to high solubility and low permeability, pseudoephedrine was provisionally classified as BCS class 3 drug.
label: Drug

text: A limitation of this study is that all volunteers were Japanese, so it remains unclear whether ethnic differences effect pharmacokinetic interactions between GT and fexofenadine.
label: Ethnic group
Herb name
Drug

text: In relation to ethnicity, there was no influence of the SLCO2B1*3 SNV on fexofenadine pharmacokinetics, although we confirmed that this polymorphism is common in Japanese population.
label: Drug
Ethnic group

text: In conclusion, we show for the first time that co‐administration of GTE markedly reduces exposure to fexofenadine in humans by inhibiting OATP1A2‐mediated intestinal absorption, whereas the pharmacokinetics of pseudoephedrine are unlikely to be influenced by co‐administration of GTE.
label: Herb name
Drug
Target
Parameter
Drug
Herb name

text: Considering that brewed GT contains more catechins and flavonoids in addition to EGCG, we propose that GT should not be taken during anti‐allergic therapy using, at least, fexofenadine.
label: Herb name
